text: The question my group wants to answer is: _________________________________
Here is a space for you to take notes. We have also suggested some of the variables for you. Create variables using the variable tool on text tiles or in the diagram tile.

• [initial number of cats]
  • [litter size]
  • [length of a cat pregnancy]
  • [ratio of female to male kittens per litter]
  • [age at which a cat is old enough to have kittens]
* Use the space below to consider how you would approach your first task.
<> First, drag the prompt from your task into this workspace using the 6 dots in the corner of that tile.
<>Then use the prompt questions at left to help you organize your thoughts.
* You can use any of the tile types (diagram, text, drawing, image, table, graph) to help you with your task.
* Make sure you label your answers with the number of the question you are answering.
Here is a space for you to take notes. Create variables using the variable tool on text tiles or in the diagram tile.

• [initial number of cats]
  • [height of the building]
  • [area of town]
  • [etc.]
A diagram for specifying variable relationships, and a drawing tile for sketches are already made for you.
Drag the questions from this Activity on the left into this workspace. Edit the text to write your answers below the questions.
Here is a space for you to take notes. Create variables using the variable tool on text tiles or drawing tiles, and develop your model in the diagram tile.
Here is a space for you to take notes. Create variables using the variable tool on text tiles or drawing tiles, and develop your model in the diagram tile.
How many people in the world are talking on their cell phones as you read this question?
Here is a space for you to take notes. Create variables using the variable tool on text tiles or drawing tiles, and develop your model in the diagram tile.
Here is a space for you to take notes. Create variables using the variable tool on text tiles or drawing tiles, and develop your model in the diagram tile.

Analyze the initial model

  • What concerns do you have about the initial model?
  • Bold the concerns that you will try to fix in your revision.

Welcome to your work space! In here, you will find information and questions. You will work both individually and in groups, so be sure to listen to your teacher about what to do when.

Some tips for this workspace:

  • You can rearrange your spaces by clicking on the top right-hand corner of the tile (where you will see 6 dots). This will allow you drag and move the tiles.
  • You can click on the bottom right corner of any tile and then drag it up or down to make it smaller or bigger.
  • You can share your work with your group-mates by using the Share slider on the top right corner, or publish your work to the whole class by clicking the button with the up-arrow next to the File menu.
  • You can also look at the work of your group-mates by clicking the Group View icon on the top bar (it looks like a window).
  • If you click on the X next to the tab called "Class Work", the Resources side of the screen on the left will collapse to give you more room to work.
Your workspace is on the right. You can create content in it by dragging tiles from any tab on the left, or by using one of the tile tools in the toolbar.
Text tiles can be used to document your ideas, make lists, and to display or define variables.

tiles.title: Toolbar buttons for the text tile

text: You can store reference data in tables.
Drawing tiles can be used to document your ideas as sketches, make annotations on top of embedded images, and to display or define variables.

tiles.title: Toolbar buttons for the drawing tile

text: Diagram tiles can be used to define and create relationships between variables.

tiles.title: Toolbar buttons for the diagram tile

text:
Test your model

It is time to test your model. Complete at least three tests. Then drag this tile into your workspace and answer the following questions:

Test 1

How are you testing your model? {Write your answer here}

What are your test results? {Write your answer here}

What do these results mean in the problem context? {Write your answer here}

Test 2

How are you testing your model? {Write your answer here}

What are your test results? {Write your answer here}

What do these results mean in the problem context? {Write your answer here}

Test 3

How are you testing your model? {Write your answer here}

What are your test results? {Write your answer here}

What do these results mean in the problem context? {Write your answer here}

Feel free to add more tests.

Compare your model with the initial model

Explain how your model compares with the initial model.

{Write your answer here}

Generalize your model

Explain how your model can be used to solve similar problems. Describe an example.

{Write your answer here}
